text: Uniontown is a city in Bourbon County, Kansas, United States. In 2020, 293 people lived there. ==History== A post office was created in 1856 about two miles east of the town. Uniontown was moved to its current place around 1865. The early settlers were loyal to the Union in the Civil War. The city was named after the Union. Throughout the twentieth century the town was served by the Missouri Pacific Railroad. ==Geography== Uniontown is at (37.847198, -94.975688). It is along the Marmaton River. The United States Census Bureau says that the city has a total area of . All of it is land. ==People== ===2020 census=== The 2020 census says that there were 293 people, 107 households, and 68 families living in Uniontown. Of the households, 79.4% owned their home and 20.6% rented their home. The median age was 31.1 years. Of the people, 91.8% were White, 2.0% were Native American, 0.7% were Asian, and 5.5% were two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.0% of the people. ===2010 census=== The 2010 census says that there were 272 people, 120 households, and 66 families living in Uniontown. ==References== ==Other websites== ;City * Uniontown - Directory of Public Officials ;Schools * USD 235, local school district ;Maps * Uniontown City Map , KDOT Category:Cities in Bourbon County, Kansas
title: Uniontown, Kansas
